title: Ask HN: How many YoE are enough to gradually get into software architecture?
text:
It makes all the sense in the world that being a software/system architect is chronologically after being a decent software engineer.

The question is, however, how many years of experience are required to slowly start preparing oneself for this big jump.

Even now, with around 3 years of experience, I already feel a deep interest in system design and architecture, but it's still very frustrating.

Tell your story please. Probably, you could also share how you learned the skill, what your your first steps were

Knifecenter Has Been Hacked
text:
I discovered this a few minutes ago and immediately reported it to them over the phone.

I use masked email (a unique email for each business) and I got a SPAM message to my unique Knifecenter email account. My girlfriend also has a Knifecenter account and got the same SPAM email titled "Walmart Payment Invoice e-Statement".

Tell HN: I have found a hardware heisenbug in my laptop
text:
I use a Lenovo x220 and this is one of the most loved laptops among the IT crowd. Sometimes I opened it after 1 hour of travel and found 0% of battery. Today I realized why it happens so.

My configuration is pretty default for Debian: when the lid is closed, the system sleeps, and when the lid is opened the system unsleeps. But if the lid opens and quickly closes due to vibration the system unsleeps and keeps working. If something heavy is running, the battery drains quickly. If you think that nothing heavier than an e-book is running then check your open e-books for any epub files opened. Atril the default viewer uses WebKit for rendering epub which means absurdly heavy CPU load which was my case.

What about the bug with the lid, it is unfixable on a program level. That reed switch is controlled by BIOS, and when the open-lid signal is received, the BIOS thing is going to be busy for several seconds doing some work to get the system unsleep. Solving the problem using bash script with asking the reed every 5 seconds seems like worse than a problem. Since the bug is hardware-caused, the solution has to be hardware as well. Bigger laptops from this series have a lock to prevent this from happening but this device has extremely little room inside of it so I understand why this model doesn't have the lock. Now I tie my laptop with rubber to prevent it from opening while traveling.

Such a pity no mobile device vendor does anything to prevent battery-powered devices from extra charge-discharge cycles.
